title: What will be the annualized rate of housing starts for October 2021?
possible_answers: More than 1.6 million but less than 1.8 million

The annualized rate of housing starts is a key measurement of new residential housing construction in the United States. The number of new housing starts took a significant dip in the late 2000s due to the housing crisis, but has been steadily climbing back to pre-recession levels ever since. There did exist another downturn in mid-2020, most likely due to a combination of the pandemic and the high cost of building materials, but even this was not enough to affect the rate for long and it has since rebounded and is continuing its upward trajectory. According to the U.S. Census Bureau and U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (2021), as of August of this year there were 1,615,000 Housing starts, a 3.9% increase above July predictions and 17.4% increase from the same time in 2020. The number of new housing starts has been flirting with the 1.6 million mark since the beginning of 2021, making an accurate prediction around this specific number difficult. According to the website ipropertymanagement.com (2021), 2020 saw 1.4 million new housing starts while the last 12 months from the time of this writing has seen the threshold number of 1.6 million. Being as this represents 95.2% of the total number of issued housing permits, an extremely high number, fluctuation is extremely possible and could result in the actual amount for October falling on either side of the line. Despite this, my prediction is that the U.S. will see a continued upward trend in new housing starts, passing the 1.6 million barrier but remaining significantly south of the nest 1.8 million threshold. I place the confidence level of this prediction at 90%, with the remaining 10% allocated to the more conservative estimate of between 1.4 and 1.6 million.  References: U.S. Census Bureau and U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development. (2021). https://www.census.gov/construction/nrc/pdf/newresconst.pdf Ipropertymanagement.com. (2021). Housing Starts and Data Statistics. https://ipropertymanagement.com/research/housing-starts.

In 2021, the monthly annualized housing starts varied between 1.447 million (in February) and 1.725 million (in March). There was a 3.93% increase in housing starts in August, after a decrease in July that was preceded by three months of continued increases. Given that many of the factors affecting the housing market have remained in a fairly consistent range since the last reported housing starts, I believe housing starts for October will remain in that range. I believe the end of coronavirus relief (eviction moratorium and unemployment), the slightly increasing mortgage rate (consistently above 3% since 9/17/2021), and ongoing material + labor shortages will prevent the October rate from exceeding 1.799 million. Additionally, there is no evidence to suggest housing starts dropping below 1.4 million.  References:
https://ycharts.com/indicators/housing_starts
http://www.mortgagenewsdaily.com/mortgage_rates/daily.aspx
https://www.reuters.com/world/us/us-housing-starts-beat-expectations-august-2021-09-21/

I did not know how much I did not know about this particular subject until I began researching it. At this point, I feel like I now know even less. With that said, here is the old college try. I think there is a 60% chance of housing starts staying between 1.4 million and 1.6 million inclusive. The market as of right now, and as the short synopsis suggest, is being widely affected by lumber shortages and other shortages with other materials. There is also the factor of labor shortages as of right now. While new single family units and homes will continue to be built, I don’t see any sign of a massive proliferation any time soon nor a decline. I think it will stay stagnant. As for less or more, the housing market, especially as it applies to new build has a volatility of its own. Therefore I’m scoring it for 20% less and 20% for more. The state of the economy however I believe will deter a number of people away from building as the cost may not outweigh the risk. With that said, there still appears to be proliferation of younger people moving to the suburbs. That could cause a slight influx but that remains to be seen and the dead line for this prediction is fast approaching with no real definitive movement going either up or down. Thankyou Taylor for the reference as far as good source material, it helped a lot.

https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/housing-starts shows a forecast band with and expected median just over 1.5m and a general downward trend. Could still come in over 1.6 but looking like slightly under.

The census data for 2021 August shows a higher uptick in housing starts compared to 2020 with an adjusted rate of  1,615,000 compared to 1,376,000 respectively. The data seems to trend towards October having higher starts and with a hot housing market I am fairly confident that housing starts will land between 1.6 and 1.8 million. I do not think we will break over 1.8 million starts as I am skeptical of current supply constraints and what impact the Delta variant of COVID-19. This skepticism leads me to think that starts are more likely to dip below 1.6 million rather than balloon past 1.8 million.  https://www.census.gov/construction/nrc/pdf/newresconst.pdf

Housing starts have not risen above 1.8 million per month since before the Great Recession, according to stats from Trading Economics. Yet the trend has also consistently topped 1.6 million starts over the last several months for the first time since the Recession. With that in mind, it would likely be impossible to ramp up building capacity to over 2 million from where it is not, but the possibility of 1.8-2.0 million starts is possible if not highly unlikely. More likely, starts will stay consistent with the trend  between 1.6 and 1.8 million.  Now onto the lower bounds: in order for starts to drop below 1.4m, something drastic would have to happen in the market to force a ~20% drop in current trends. Inflation is the most obvious culprit because it makes housing construction more expensive-- yet inflation has been consistently rising since Biden took office and housing starts still reached a post-Covid high. Covid itself could present another curve ball, but with the vast majority of the country having either vaccinated or natural immunity it is unlikely to have a major impact on the housing market at this point. Lastly, mortgage rates would have to sky rocket to really reduce the number of starts, which, despite their modest fluctuation, doesn't seem too likely. That narrows it down between 1.4-1.6 and 1.6-1.8 million as the two most likely scenarios, consistent with recent and long term trends as well as external constraints. In August 2021 there were 1.615 starts, right on the cusp-- so it can go either direction. Some Fermi questions we might consider from here are whether people have money to build houses and what the seasonal constraints are.  A 2019 Census Bureau Report finds that houses take an average of 7 months to build from start to finish-- so a housing start in October would run primarily through the winter. Building a house during the winter increases costs (on site heating, snow clearing) and reduces productivity with shorter hours of daylight. Couple that with labor shortages and the cost of hiring construction workers goes up a great deal. With inflation as high as it is, home starts might be reduced from the current trend in order to save a little extra cash after the winter in the hopes of more favorable (seasonal and financial) conditions. Yet people are fed up with Covid and have extra money in their pockets from 2 years of staying home, so those who can afford it may just want to get their home built rather than putting it off any longer to save a few extra bucks. This would be a smaller, wealthier, segment of the population however.  Thus, I think a declining trend to 1.4-1.6 is most likely, but a steady trend between 1.6-1.8 is not unreasonable either.

On 18 August 2021, Trading and Economics reported a 7% decrease to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.543 million units in July of 2021, while on 21 September 2021, housing in the US was up 3.9% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.615 million units August of 2021, rebounding from a downwardly revised 6.2% fall in July beating market forecasts of 1.554 million (2021). On 24 September 2021, the Department of Defense(DoD) temporarily authorized increases in the 2021 Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) rates for 56 housing markets across the US. The increased BAH rates affected service members took effect on 1 October and will expire on 31 December 2021 (defense.gov). Mike Fratantoni, the chief economist for the Mortgage Banker Association, stated, “Builders are also reporting difficulty obtaining other inputs like appliances, and these supply-chain constraints are holding back a housing market that should otherwise be picking up speed, given the strong demand for buying fueled by an improving job market and low mortgage rates” (Olick, 2021). BAH factors are a solid indicator of the housing market; along with past statistical data and pandemic factors, the annualized rate will likely fall between 1.4 million and 1.6 million inclusive (50%), and more than 1.6 million but less than 1.8 million (50%) (moderate confidence). https://www.defense.gov/News/Releases/Release/Article/2788871/dod-authorizes-a-temporary-increase-to-2021-basic-allowance-for-housing-rates-f for Certain Locations /.
Trading and Economics (2021). US Housing Starts Fall 7%. https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/housing-starts.
Trading and Economics (2021). US Housing Starts Top Forecasts. https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/housing-starts.
Olick, D (2021). Home Construction sees Biggest Drop Since Pandemic Hit. Here’s Why Home construction sees the biggest drop since the pandemic hit. Here's why (cnbc.com)

Looking at the graph from a more narrow perspective, particularly the months of October to December. There seems to be a sort of trend where units typically increase in October, only for it to begin significant declines by December. From a more historical perspective, almost every 10 years from 1960 there has been at least one sharp spike in decline. Further elaborating on this, the only decline lower than the 10 year decline cycle occurred in October-1966 between 1960 to 1970.  However, in between these 10 years, typically 2-5, there are significant rises in units. The only time this decline didn't occur in the 10 year cycle didn't occur was between 1990 to 2000. What's even more interesting about the years after 1990 is how the graph becomes consistent. Unlike the years prior to 1990, the grap shows a start contrast in fluctuations. But the years after 1990 shows great consistency before plummeting. To support this, from 2000 to 2010, a massive spike occurred. A spike that hit 478, a number far lower than any decline in the past 50 years prior before 2010. But from 2010, there was yet again another decline on April 2020, but only after having a smooth rise just like the years between 1990 and 2000.  If the historical trend is anything to go by, we may be approaching yet another significant decline in the next 6 months to one year.

The United States Census Bureau is the authority for US Housing and Urban Development (HUD) and as such is the primary information hub for housing, real estate, and related analysis and predictions according to industry trends and state events.
4. What is a seasonally adjusted annual rate?
Most of the seasonally adjusted series are shown as seasonally adjusted annual rates (SAAR). The seasonally adjusted annual rate is the seasonally adjusted monthly value multiplied by 12. The benefit of the annual rate is that not only can one monthly estimate be compared with another; monthly data can also be compared with an annual total. The seasonally adjusted annual rate is neither a forecast nor a projection; rather it is a description of the rate of building permits, housing starts, housing completions, or new home sales in the particular month for which they are calculated.
url source: https://www.census.gov/construction/nrc/faqs/faqs_nrc_release.html
Using data from https://www.census.gov/construction/nrc/pdf/newresconst.pdf, and https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/housing-starts to demonstrate the 2021 historical adjustments in the seasonally adjusted annual rate per month to provide as accurate a prediction as possible for October 2021.  
September 2021 demonstrated a 3.9% SAAR moving up from 1.55 million to 1.615 million and August 2021  had a -7% and an overall trend line including Oct 2020 to Oct 2021 projecting a starting value directly below 1.65 million, approximately 1.648 million an increase of approximately .97% on current trend.

Other trends continuing to January of 2021 to exclude atypical fluctuations due to COVID-19 complications shows an overall moderate increase with 3 month fluctuations which even in 2021 are a product of COVID-19 events both in restrictions and limited production but also in subsidies, job market recovery initiatives, a year plus of employment providers utilizing online platforms and growing them for productivity’s sake, and government action specifically designed to improve economic conditions.  These factors have combined to allow increases in the SAAR and though October 21 would indicate a negative month, by microtrend, the overall initiatives targeting the balancing of the US housing sector should provide an overall improving trend for Oct ’21 though the overall trend of gradual gains/losses would indicate a marginal gain for Oct ’21 as the most likely event.    
The likelihood of positive trends continuing into November and December 21 for the US SAAR is unlikely both historically and practically as weather changes and a majority of the US is affected by inclimate weather housing changes become less and common during winter months. https://time.com/nextadvisor/mortgages/best-time-to-buy-a-home/ HUD initiatives specifically for 2021 come into effect most accuately in October of the proposed fiscal year as the fy ends in September so the potential for proposed elements to actually take effect as soon as possible is in October, October of 2021 with a new administration and its proposals in a COVID-19 recovering environment adjusting national priorities shows an overall increase in most housing and development projects administrated by HUD.  Specific emphasis given to LEAD housing and community development, almost doubling the budget specifically for it.  https://www.hud.gov/sites/dfiles/CFO/documents/FY21_HUDCongressionalJustifications.pdf Overall CPI living expenses are also increasing, contributing to evaluative techniques for predicting housing increases as the CPI concerning Food at ~3% and energy at ~25%, most of the increase since July does demonstrate cause for concern at the prospect of an increase in the SAAR for the US in Oct ’21.   Considering all the positive trending data and infusion projects the single greatest element I feel will have an impact on the SAAR for Oct 2021 statistics is the ending of forbearances put in place during COVID-19 to forestall foreclosures and evictions that expire at the end of September, directly impacting Oct Housing sector activities.  The extended periods of coverage combined with the massive return to work statistics (even though many sectors are still in the negative for workforce requirements) the general population has the capital to return to the housing market increasingly each month, the months of suspended debt and debt requirements will allow property owners to return to eviction processes and provide recourse for lost revenue.  These actions to recoup will assuredly affect individuals who would be participating in the requesting of permits, builds, and sales.  
Having said this, I still believe that the amount of individuals returning to work at approximately 700,000 per month, government subsidies, and constant home overvalutation will persist through the month of September and affect the Oct ’21 publication numbers but will increase only slightly to the tune of approximately 1% at near 1,650,000.   The annualized rate of housing starts for October 2021 (seasonally adjusted) will be: 1%, at ~1.65million.

I determined that this problem is largely a macro trend problem. I have used data from FRED in the past to make forecasts of economic data, and this is little different. I started by gathering potential explanatory variables from the FRED database. I began my analysis with the following variables: •	Date
•	Existing Single-Family Home Sales
•	Median Number of Months on Sales Market for Newly Completed Homes
•	Monthly Supply of Houses in the United States
•	New Houses Sold by Stage of Construction, Not Started
•	New One Family Homes for Sale in the United States
•	New Privately-Owned Housing Units Authorized but Not Started: Total
•	New Privately-Owned Housing Units Authorized in Permit-Issuing Places:
•	New Privately-Owned Housing Units Started: Total Units
•	Producer Price Index by Commodity: Lumber and Wood Products: Lumber My dependent variable was New Privately-Owned Housing Units Started: Total Units advanced by two months. In other words, my model was designed to use data from January to forecast the value of housing starts in March. This is necessary because the most recent data available in the FRED data sets is from August, with which I must forecast October. After doing multiple regression analysis on these as well as lagged versions of these, I ended up with the following variables in my regression model, all but one of which were significant at the 2% level or better. The least significant variable was Permits (lagged 3 months) at 6.07%. All data is sourced from the FRED database by the names shown. •	New Privately-Owned Housing Units Authorized but Not Started: Total
•	Median Number of Months on Sales Market for Newly Completed Homes
•	Monthly Supply of Houses in the United States
•	New Houses Sold by Stage of Construction, Not Started
•	[Lagged 3 months] New Privately-Owned Housing Units Authorized in Permit-Issuing Places The resulting model has an R2 of .9248 and a Standard Error of 82.43. This translates to a 95% confidence interval of +/- 163,100 housing starts. Given the range of selections in the GJP are in 200,000 house intervals this seems like an acceptable degree of confidence.

Based on August 2021 values for my independent variables, my model predicts 1,688 housing starts in October 2021. There is 95% confidence the actual number of starts will be between 1,525 and 1,851. Specifically, the GJP asks for confidence related to levels of 1.4M - 1.6M, and 1.6M - 1.8M. My model suggests that the probability of starts being less than 1.4M is negligible (.0003), the probability of starts being below 1.6M is .144, the probability of being below 1.8M is .912, and being below 2.0M is .999.
Thus my confidence in the 1.4M to 1.6M range is 14%, my confidence in the 1.6M to 1.8M range is 77%, and my confidence in the 1.8M to 2.0M range is 9%.

Reason: According to the 5 year trend from Trading Economics the annualized rate of housing dips around October of every year following a spike in the summer months, a decline, and then an upward trend which falls in November or December. Currently the rate is just above 1,600, my guess is that this is not the peak quite yet, and that it will stay just above the 1.6 million mark, however there is still a chance that October is the peak and that it will decline to just below that mark.  Sources: https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/housing-starts (Links to an external site.) https://ycharts.com/indicators/housing_starts

While studying multiple data charts on housing starts in this fiscal year up to August, the average is 1.55 million and the lowest this fiscal year was 1.47 million. So, there is no proof or data supporting housing starts dropping below 1.4 million. The largest drop in housing starts was March to April, by which it dropped from 1.725 million to 1.514 million. Also, as the U.S. is on an upward recover from the pandemic, there is a likely chance that the housing market and economy will be steady making a probable outcome that housing starts will stay around 1.6 million. Lumber prices are a factor as well to housing starts, which in July, lumber was at its lowest price. This resulted in more housing starts in August. As of Oct 1st, lumber prices are in a slight incline which could lower housing starts but its marginal, which it will stay close to 1.6 million. If the housing market increases and lumber prices stay steady during October, there will be an unlikely chance that housing starts will be above 1.6 million. The housing starts fell to $1.543 million in July 2021 before rebounding to $1.615 in August. This increase of housing starts is likely to increase for September as the price for lumber continues to drop and get back to a more average price for lumber. Climate plays a big part how people spend money. Most people would think building a new house makes more sense in the spring/summer time frame, but as the numbers have shown, even with an increase in price of lumber, the numbers for July are down. I contribute this to a reciprocal thought, where the average house takes 9 months to build. Let's say October for instance, you lay the foundation and 9 months later (June/July) your house is complete. This allows parents with children the ability to move in when the weather is good and school is out of session. This forecast may change slightly after the September numbers are released on 19OCT. While housing starts drop significantly in July, permits were up in the same month, usually a sign of housing start to increase over the following month or two. In 2020 housing starts were up 10% from August to October, but that was after a huge plunge in April, and COVID may have impacted housing starts last year as it did the rest of the economy, so the 10% could very well have been the rebound, like in the stock market. The period between August and October in 2019 was down 3.9%, in 2018 down 6.2% and in 2017 up 7.7%, so historically over the last four years there is no set pattern.

The U.S. Census Bureau and the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development jointly announced the new residential construction statistics for August 2021 showing privately‐owned housing starts in August were at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1,615,000.  This is 3.9 percent above the revised July estimate of 1,554,000. The August rate for units in buildings with five units or more was 530,000. Lumber spot prices have fallen, but other essential building materials such as windows, cabinets and electrical components remain in short supply. Higher prices for single family homes and an increased demand for rental properties will likely contribute to the overall numbers. 
(U.S. Census Bureau and the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, September 21, 2021 Monthly New Residential Construction, August 2021)

First attempt at estimating housing, so if anyone is reading this please keep that in mind. Last time we were above 2M units was October 2005, so I'm very much discounting that number. Now the most interesting thing is that the band is fairly narrow given that Dec 2018 was down at 1.095M units and we peaked at 1.733M units in March 2021. Using the indicators above as a good starting point here is what I see that I am weighing into my prediction. 1. Lumber prices are bonkers - back in April it was $1074 . Now it is off the high of $1645, but still sticking around $1327 for the spot price. I don't know what units lumber is traded in, but we're at a 23% premium relative to prices then and that makes building very costly. 2. Labor is likely in good supply, but we might be peaking at the number of qualified laborers given current market conditions. I don't know this well enough to have a decisive conclusion, but I suspect that so many people in construction have been sidelined that it may be more difficult to find builders than one would necessarily expect. My friend who tiles says that a ton of people are also looking for remodels on their existing houses, so that takes up supply as well. 3. Mortgage rates seem to be climbing slowly but surely. November - January was 2.68 - 2.74 and we are now at 2.96 for the latest month with the two prior months being over 3% for rates. This will slightly suppress demand as well because it is not as cheap to buy as it was previously. This means fewer homeowners buying. Overall, there is a huge pent up demand for housing in this country - mostly in urban and suburban areas with rural areas finding themselves losing population to larger cities with more opportunity. This is the biggest factor driving the production higher. This is going to be offset during most of the next 5 months by the factors I mention above - without that I could easily see us in the 1.8-2M zone.I'll appreciate having more data to look at now that I have given this an initial prediction. Quick chart for easy reference:
We've been above 1.4M since August 2020, so unlikely to be there
1.4-1.8 is a good range and that's why 90% of my prediction is focused there
1.8-2M is possible if I have overestimated the depressive effects of the forces above
2M is also possible, but less likely so it also gets a nod.

I think that the housing market in the US is currently in a short-term bubble due to supply shocks due to COVID and people wanting to escape violence and oppression in large cities. As lockdowns end and the effects of the US color revolution wind down, the demand will fall off the cliff. I don't discount the possibility that some speculators will still be building spec houses hoping for a post-bubble pop bounce.

Mutikani. L., (2021. May, 18). Surging lumber prices weigh on U.S. homebuilding. Reuters. Business. Retrieved from
https://www.reuters.com/business/us-housing-starts-drop-sharply-april-2021-05-18/ U.S. homebuilding fell more than expected in April, likely pulled down by soaring prices for lumber and other materials, but construction remains supported by an acute shortage of previously owned homes on the market. The plunge in homebuilding reported by the Commerce Department on Tuesday was concentrated in the single-family housing market segment. The number of houses authorized for construction but not yet started increased to the highest level since 1999, suggesting hesitancy on the part of builders. Housing starts tumbled 9.5% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.569 million units last month. Data for March was revised lower to a rate of 1.733 million units, still the highest level since June 2006, from the previously reported 1.739 million units. Economists polled by Reuters had forecast starts would fall to a rate of 1.710 million units in April.

My thoughts on various influencing factors:
+ the trend towards more WFH and moving away from cities is a structural one, and demand for new housing in various areas will stay elevated for a while
? price of lumber is hampering construction, but is also due to supply shortages brought on by COVID; with Canada's vaccination rate climbing quickly now, the supply issues will probably start to resolve
- price of labour is high due to unemployment benefits (though I'm not sure how much this impacts the construction industry), and I could see them being extended again
- concerns about inflation are growing, and many predict the Fed will be forced to raise rates much sooner than they are projecting
- reopening means more money spent on consumption, and less on investment (including housing), home renos, etc.
most likely will be between 1.6 and 1.8 but there is more risk of a downside than an upside
I believe there will be a slow down with economic outlook and supply of product.

Commodity prices were expected to spike then stabilize late summer/early fall. Lumber futures are down 30% over the last 8 days and, while supply shortages are likely to have prices higher they should come down enough that framing picks up again. Tariff increases on Canadian softwood likely don't come into play until November, if that is a factor in costs there could be a builder induced bump in Sept/Oct. Other supply chains should normalize late this year as well although the trend of putting a foundation in (technically a start) could suppress future numbers. Rates are expected to stay low but if talk goes towards raising them in the fall it could give a slight bump to starts. All in all it looks like the fall could be pretty normal with so many factors countering each other

There is no base case for what is going on now, except maybe early 1970s. The FED is clearly wrong about inflation being transitory. The longer inflation remains high interest rates should climb. I expect 4%+ inflation for at least the next four months, probably longer.  What makes this so hard to predict is the market doesn't follow fundamentals the way it used to. The government is holding interest rates artificially low. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are buying up nearly all mortgages on the back end, meaning that commercial banks no longer hold on to hardly any mortgages. However, Fannie and Freddy are both supposedly profit seeking entities even if they are quasi government organizations so as inflation stays high interest rates should climb. But we also never know when the FED is going to increase their purchase of mortgage-backed securities. They certainly are not going to decrease their purchases anywhere in the next few years.
I looked at the graph. This is what I took away from it.

When I check out the numbers in excel and use a linear trend since January of 2014 to forecast October (forecast.linear function in Excel) I come up with 1.49 million. The FRED graph with that trend line drawn on it is here [1]. The pandemic is weird so I'm not counting on the recent highs and am putting more weight around the trend since things might be stabilized a bit more by October. That said, I am skewing toward the higher end because with low interest rates and the economy accelerating after the pandemic recession I think it's possible we continue to see higher housing numbers. [1] https://fred.stlouisfed.org/graph/?g=EbPv

Historical data has shown October to remain as a strong month for housing. Even with the uncertainty in the Lumber market the 30 year mortgage is still relatively on the lower end than in the past. On going with that 2021 has showed average rates lower than 2020 which was the lowest average rate in a long time. If Lumber prices come down from the recent highs I would expect higher numbers which is my justification for the 29%.

Lumber supply shortage and price crisis seems to have eased since 10 May 2021 and May continue to do so, as sources from Europe diversify supply.
